threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
tl;dr version: It will be banned on all Smogon formats and people in VGC will bitch about it until it gets banned from there too

In the games Terastal is used by NPCs in the dumbest way possible so players might to immediatly realize the implications of this mechanic, but in actual competitive environments this is busted beyond belief, worse than Dynamax in my opinion.

Dynamax only lasted 3 turns and what happened in practice 90% of the time was that you counter-Dynamaxed to stop the opponent from sweeping your team with their own Dynamax, since unless you were a retard you could guess the designated Dynamax sweeper from team preview and plan ahead of time.

What Terastal does in practice is replacing a pokemon with another one that plays the same role but gets insane offensive boosts from multiple STABs, including a supower-powered one.
What makes it busted is that it persists even after switching out. If it was just for 3 turns like Dynamax it would actually be balanced.
Tera Blast being Hidden Power on steroids is also a problem and basically turns every matchup into a 50/50 because now knowing what coverage mons usually run means jack shit.

I expect this mechanic to be banned within a month on Smogon and to be banned on VGC after the first one. The dislike Dynamax received will be nothing compared to this.

>>52159533
At some point another kid's franchise will come along that will topple Pokemon for the 6-to-10-year-old demographic. The Millennials will lose interest gradually, just as they've done before and will do again, and the Zoomers will start having families and jobs and won't have time for old hobbies.

Pokemon relies on fresh blood being injected into the fandom every couple of years. Gen 6 brought in the Millennials who had left by appealing to their sense of Gen 1 nostalgia. Yo-Kai Watch threatened Pokemon's dominance during Gen 7, but Game Freak adapted and survived. Gen 8 coasted because the pandemic meant that everybody was stuck at home and had time to play games and rediscover old favourites.

Gen 9 is riding the wave of Gen 8's success, but it's not sustainable. At some point something's gotta give. Whether Gen 10's success is up in the air. Will 10-year-olds care in 2026? Who knows.

>What's this all about?
Showderp is a game where one of us declares himself the champ and takes a ragtag team of six Pokémon assembled by anons into an online competitive Pokémon battling simulator.
To quote one of Showdown's mods...
>@MacChaeger: None of these people are youtubers
>@MacChaeger: They impersonate verlis to to gain notoriety and attract new members
>@MacChaeger: These people regularly trick others into getting locked
>@MacChaeger: this is the single most toxic group of players on PS

>How does it work?
After the current champ calls "new champ", the first anon to claim the title is our champ. He uses the first six legal Pokémon suggested after his claim as his team. Champ can also call "new team" when the old one became stale (rule of thumb: 40-60 minutes). Champ plays in National Dex unless specified otherwise.
Absolutely no experience is necessary and everything is done in-browser.

Rules
1. Champ can't forfeit, intentionally throw a match, or timer stall.
2. Champ may not edit a set without the suggester's permission.
3. All Pokémon must be nicknamed. If the sugg didn't have a name, champ makes one up.
4. Don't suggest twice, unless your last sugg was 15 minutes ago or champ explicitly asked for resuggs.
5. Champ should replace resuggs with fresh suggestions that come in later.
6. Don't spam the catalog with threads.

>>52158911
>Every single element (and therefore compond) is poisonous at a certain dosage.
Except in many cases it's not naturally feasible to poison yourself with most things that are otherwise healthy or harmless. For example, oxygen. You'd need advanced technology to poison yourself with oxygen.
In other cases, like with "too much Vitamin A" our body has ways of limiting what nutrients go where in your body so that you don't get toxicity. "Vitamin A toxicity" was actually caused by cadmium-contaminated liver, not vitamin A itself. Then there are things like heavy metals that you shouldn't have at all because they are harmful at any level.
Your example makes no sense. Yes, we're made of carbon, but no we're not made of carbon monoxide. The carbon in our bodies is chemically different than carbon monoxide. The carbon in meat is not the same as carbon monoxide which at high enough concentrations prevents our hemoglobin from binding with enough oxygen to keep us alive. But even at lower concentrations there can be cellular damage from oxygen deprivation, or at least more stress (harmful) put on the body by having to exert a lot of energy to unbind carbon monoxide from hemoglobin. Stop being retarded and acting like it's okay to have toxins injected into you because you're allegedly breathing in more toxins than have been injected. It's all bad.

>>52158351
I loved it. There's a lot elements there that I wish pokemon would implement. Like the field abilities (like HM) being attached to certain monsters, for example, you can ride an specific swiming monster to swim or an specific monster to fly, or to break a stone and the like.
And yes, I know Arceus sorta do this, but only with one pokemon per ability, in MH you can ride all the capturable monsters.

The battle system is simple (rock, paper, scizors), but not bad by any means. Battles with tough monsters are more about pattern memorization (just like a normal MH).

The world map is kind of small, but at least for me it was good enough.

And well, just factor in all the famous elements from any MH game (like the crafting of the armors/weapons) and you got a good game. Not a masterpiece by any means, but a good game.
